awd_titl_txt: Sea Surface Temperature-Forced Monsoon Evolution and Variability in West Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
The West African monsoon delivers most of the annual rainfall to the Sahel region in a short but intense rainy season. Since agriculture remains the dominant economic activity in terms of percent of population engaged, understanding and predicting the variability in both the magnitude and timing of the monsoon season is especially important and potentially devastating if not prepared for. This work;will directly contribute to improving seasonal to interannual prediction of monsoon rainfall. The results of this work will be highly relevant to climate prediction organizations interested in helping the Sahel such as the International Research Institute for Climate and Society and its long-standing partners in West Africa. Through various channels, information from the study can inform applications;of climate information for better decision-making in the Sahel. The work will also support a graduate student. Knowledge gathered from this study will also contribute to the teaching of climate and society in the School for International and Public Affairs (SIPA) at Columbia University programs.

The goal of this project is to improve the understanding and prediction of the West African summer monsoon, specifically response to changes in sea surface temperatures in the surrounding tropical oceans. Information on sea surface temperature fluctuations is routinely available and is important for climate prediction. The seasonal amount of Sahel monsoon rains, varies from year to year sometimes dropping to drought levels with serious effects on society. This variability has been linked to sea surface temperature fluctuations in remote and nearby ocean areas. Past studies have shown a that summer monsoon rains tend to weaken and sometimes fail when eastern tropical Pacific sea surface temperatures are relatively warm, a state known as  the El Niño. Rains tend to be strong and plentiful when the east tropical pacific are relatively cool, during the La Nina phase. However, this association is not steady because the region is also sensitive to temperature changes in other basins, such as the tropical Atlantic and the Indian Oceans. 

Utilizing an atmospheric global climate model, in which different sea surface temperature scenarios are prescribed in the global ocean mimicking what is found in observations, this research will elucidate how the monsoon responds to changes in local and remote sea surface temperature changes in different basins, acting separately and together. By understanding the response pattern and the mechanisms of momentum, heat and moisture transport as a function of time, it is anticipated that possibilities of prediction of monsoon rainfall, based on pre-season sea surface temperatures conditions, will be advanced. This experimental method also provides a measure of "signal-to-noise" ratio in the monsoon rainfall. Putting the observations in that perspective will help frame better the prediction uncertainties, also helping advance the quality of monsoon season prediction.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to advance the understanding of the large rainfall variations in sub-Saharan, African summer monsoon region and its dependence on forces external to the regions. We focused on the Sahel region, which is the densely populated part of sub-Saharan North Africa, where farmers and herders of livestalk critically depend on the vagaries of short- and long-term variations in rainfall and temperature. We addressed both short- and long-term Sahel rainfall variations in nature and their representation in model simulations. 

Our study began by examining the response of the African monsoon to monthly and seasonal sea surface temperature (SST) changes in the tropical Pacific and Atlantic Oceans before and during the monsoon season. It has long been known that these pre-season and in-season SST changes determine the character of the Sahel rainy season and whether it is drier or wetter than normal. The outcome of this part of the project was expected to aid in predicting the quality of the rainy season ahead of the summer months. We aimed our research at understanding how SST variations in the tropical North Atlantic affect the adverse response of the rainy season to El Niño, a Pacific phenomenon that leads to droughts in the Sahel. Here we found that when tropical North Atlantic SST are relatively warm at the beginning of the monsoon season the El Niño impact in the region will be less sever and even reversed. However, when the tropical North Atlantic is relatively cold at the beginning of the season, the El Niño drying influence will be exacerbated. We found that climate models can simulate this effect if given the right pre-season SST conditions and thus can be useful in seasonal prediction.

Extending or study to include the longer-term Sahel rainfall variability, we turned our attention to the ability of coupled climate models to simulate the changes observed in Sahel rainfall throughout the 20th – early 21st century, referred to as the “historical period”. We were concerned with the multi-decadal variations in Sahel rainfall, which were expressed in a devastating decline in rainfall in the 1970’s and 80’s and the partial recovery of the rainfall later in the century and early 21st century. These changes were perceived to be driven by a combination of internal climate variations related to the interaction between the oceans and the atmosphere in the Atlantic and Pacific Basins and the impact of the century timescale increase in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and industrial pollution, that is anthropogenic aerosol (AA) emissions. To study these effects and their expression in climate models we looked at the output of multiple model runs executed under the World Climate Research Program (WCRP), Coupled Climate Model Intercomparison (CMIP) phases 5 and 6 (CMIP 5 and CMIP 6). Using the fact that all these models were forced with the same GHG and AA emissions, we compared the multi-model average of Sahel rainfall simulations during the historical period to observations. The multi-model average severely diminishes the impact of each model, random internal variability and thus represents the “forced” rainfall response. We found that CMIP 5 models simulate the multi-decadal rainfall variation to some extent but at a considerably attenuated amplitude. That is, they show a response time change that correlates with observation but has much weaker forced signal. CMIP 6 models, however, fail in their rainfall simulations altogether. We were further able to attribute the model discrepancy to primarily the models’ inability to simulate well the oceans’ SST response to GHG and AA forcing. Furthermore, a study of the models’ residual variability, that is the individual model variations outside of the forced response, revealed that the models also have weak internal ocean-atmosphere variability such that they are not able to reproduce well Sahel rainfall variations due to internal climate variability. These results reflect badly on state-of-the-art coupled climate models and their ability to provide reliable projections of Sahel future rainfall variations.
